title: How to Make Your Own Tortillas

steps.headline: Gather your ingredients.
steps.description:
This recipe makes 8 tortillas. Here are the ingredients you'll need to make tasty flour tortillas:
4 cups of flour
1 tsp. baking powder
1 tsp. salt
1 cup of water (many substitute warm milk for a fluffier texture)
1/2 cup vegetable shortening or lard

steps.headline: Mix flour, salt, & baking powder in a large medium/large bowl.
steps.description: Make sure your bowl is big enough to accommodate all your ingredients.

steps.headline: Cut in shortening/lard until lumps are gone.
steps.description: Use a pastry cutter or fork; don't work the dough too much.

steps.headline: Make a hole in the center of the dry ingredients.
Add water, about a half a cup at a time, and work mixture into a dough.
Knead until smooth.
steps.description: The dough should be slightly sticky but not hard. You can add slightly more water or flour if needed.

steps.headline: Cover and set aside for 10 minutes.
steps.description: This will let the baking powder work the dough into a fluffier tortilla mix.

steps.headline: Make the dough into balls about the size of eggs.
Using a rolling pin, roll each dough ball into about a 6 inch (15.2 cm) circle.
steps.description: Flour your work surface before you roll the tortillas.

steps.headline: Heat griddle or skillet on medium heat.
steps.description: You can apply a little bit of oil, grease, or lard, or you can go without.

steps.headline: Cook tortilla 1/2 to 1 minute on each side.
steps.description: If it starts to bubble up, that's long enough.

steps.headline: Flip tortilla to the other side and cook for a few seconds.
Continue until all your dough is cooked.
Experiment with different kinds of tortillas.
Gather your ingredients.
steps.description:
This recipe makes 24 tortillas. Here are the ingredients you'll need to make tasty corn tortillas:
2 cups masa harina (preferably Maseca brand)
1 1/2 cups water
1/2 teaspoon kosher salt

steps.headline: Whisk masa and salt in a medium bowl.
steps.description: Make sure salt is evenly distributed in the masa.

steps.headline: Stir in water, a little at a time, until dough begins to form.
Knead the masa until dough begins to form.
steps.description:
The dough should have the consistency of Play-Doh: springy and firm but also slightly dry. Add more water by tablespoons if the dough is too dry; add more masa if the dough is too wet. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7f\/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-16Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-16Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7f\/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-16Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-16Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Measuring out one heaping tablespoon of dough, flatten the dough into small, round tortillas.
Check for the right consistency before you cook the tortillas.
steps.description:
If the dough crumbles, it is too dry — add more water. If the dough sticks to the plastic on the press, or to the rolling pin, it is too wet — add more masa. This will be your final chance to get the consistency right before cooking. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b7\/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-18Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-18Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b7\/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-18Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-18Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Decide whether you want to press all your dough before you cook or press as you cook.
steps.description: The tortillas won't take long to cook, so you may want to have them all pressed before you begin cooking. If you're working with a tortilla press, you should have enough time to press tortillas while you cook.

steps.headline: Heat cast-iron pan over medium high heat.
steps.description: Cast iron pans distribute heat evenly and quickly, so they are best for cooking tortillas, but any non-stick pan will do the job in a pinch.

steps.headline: Brush the tortillas lightly with oil and place on the pan to cook.
steps.description:
Cook 1-2 minutes on one side, or until slightly charred and edges begin to curl. Flip onto opposite side and cook for 15 more seconds. Remove from heat. If using a cast-iron pan, it's okay to cook more than one tortilla at a time. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a5\/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-21Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-21Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/a5\/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-21Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-21Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Repeat process with remaining dough.
steps.description: Keep the tortillas warm by wrapping them in a clean kitchen towel if serving immediately.

text:
Flour Tortillas Gather your ingredients. This recipe makes 8 tortillas. Here are the ingredients you'll need to make tasty flour tortillas: 4 cups of flour 1 tsp. baking powder 1 tsp. salt 1 cup of water (many substitute warm milk for a fluffier texture) 1/2 cup vegetable shortening or lard Mix flour, salt, & baking powder in a large medium/large bowl. Make sure your bowl is big enough to accommodate all your ingredients. Cut in shortening/lard until lumps are gone. Use a pastry cutter or fork; don't work the dough too much. Make a hole in the center of the dry ingredients. Add water, about a half a cup at a time, and work mixture into a dough. Knead until smooth. The dough should be slightly sticky but not hard. You can add slightly more water or flour if needed. Cover and set aside for 10 minutes. This will let the baking powder work the dough into a fluffier tortilla mix. Make the dough into balls about the size of eggs. Using a rolling pin, roll each dough ball into about a 6 inch (15.2 cm) circle. Flour your work surface before you roll the tortillas. Heat griddle or skillet on medium heat. You can apply a little bit of oil, grease, or lard, or you can go without. Cook tortilla 1/2 to 1 minute on each side. If it starts to bubble up, that's long enough. Flip tortilla to the other side and cook for a few seconds. 20-30 seconds should be enough. Continue until all your dough is cooked. Experiment with different kinds of tortillas. Now that you know how to make tortillas, you can change up the method a bit! Some simple touches to this basic recipe can add spice, flair, or sweetness to an otherwise simple flour tortilla. Add a little bit of cinnamon and sugar to your basic flour tortilla recipe for a sweet, cinnamon-y kick. Deep fry them if you want and add the cinnamon/sugar mix right after they come out of the oil. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Add a bit of chipotle peppers and adobo to your flour tortilla recipe for a spicy kick. These tortillas come packed with a kind of salsa already in them! {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Add some chopped sun-dried tomatoes to your flour tortilla recipe for some savory richness. The perfect accompaniment to fish tacos or chicken mole. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet3.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet3.jpg/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-13Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Corn Tortillas Gather your ingredients. This recipe makes 24 tortillas. Here are the ingredients you'll need to make tasty corn tortillas: 2 cups masa harina (preferably Maseca brand) 1 1/2 cups water 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt Whisk masa and salt in a medium bowl. Make sure salt is evenly distributed in the masa. Stir in water, a little at a time, until dough begins to form. Knead the masa until dough begins to form. The dough should have the consistency of Play-Doh: springy and firm but also slightly dry. Add more water by tablespoons if the dough is too dry; add more masa if the dough is too wet. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-16Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-16Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-16Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-16Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Measuring out one heaping tablespoon of dough, flatten the dough into small, round tortillas. Remember that corn tortillas are traditionally smaller than flour tortillas. Use a tortilla press lined with plastic wrap for even, more uniform-looking tortillas. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-17Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-17Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} If you don't have a tortilla press, use a rolling pin for more artisanal tortillas. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-17Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-17Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-17Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-17Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Check for the right consistency before you cook the tortillas. If the dough crumbles, it is too dry — add more water. If the dough sticks to the plastic on the press, or to the rolling pin, it is too wet — add more masa. This will be your final chance to get the consistency right before cooking. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-18Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-18Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-18Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-18Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Decide whether you want to press all your dough before you cook or press as you cook. The tortillas won't take long to cook, so you may want to have them all pressed before you begin cooking. If you're working with a tortilla press, you should have enough time to press tortillas while you cook. Heat cast-iron pan over medium high heat. Cast iron pans distribute heat evenly and quickly, so they are best for cooking tortillas, but any non-stick pan will do the job in a pinch. Brush the tortillas lightly with oil and place on the pan to cook. Cook 1-2 minutes on one side, or until slightly charred and edges begin to curl. Flip onto opposite side and cook for 15 more seconds. Remove from heat. If using a cast-iron pan, it's okay to cook more than one tortilla at a time. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-21Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-21Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-21Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-Your-Own-Tortillas-Step-21Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Repeat process with remaining dough. Keep the tortillas warm by wrapping them in a clean kitchen towel if serving immediately.
